headline: Southern-Style Buttermilk Fried Chicken
description: This buttermilk fried chicken is a southern recipe with a spicy buttermilk marinade and a seasoned flour coating that fries up golden brown and crisp.

video.description: A recipe for perfectly crispy, double-dredged fried chicken.
video.name: Southern-Style Buttermilk Fried Chicken

name: Southern-Style Buttermilk Fried Chicken

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk together buttermilk, mustard, salt, pepper, and cayenne in a bowl.
Pour buttermilk marinade into a resealable plastic bag. Add chicken pieces, coat with marinade, squeeze out excess air, and seal the bag. Marinate in the refrigerator for 2 to 8 hours.
Combine flour, baking powder, garlic powder, and onion powder in another resealable plastic bag; shake to mix thoroughly.

Working with one piece at a time, transfer marinated chicken to the dry ingredient bag, seal the bag, and shake well to coat. After all chicken pieces are coated, repeat the process by dipping them in buttermilk marinade and shaking in the dry coating again. Then heat oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat. Place chicken on the pan.

Fry chicken in batches in hot oil, turning chicken occasionally, until golden brown and juices run clear. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the meat should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).

review.reviewBody: I always make a seasoned flour/cornstarch mix with Paprika, Lawrys Season Salt and garlic. I take the marinated chicken and coat it in plain cornstarch and then back into marinade and then in the seasoned flour/cornstarch mix and then fry.

Terrible recipe. Chicken is still edible, but absolutely zero flavor. Followed the recipe step by step perfectly, even let the chicken marinade for the full 8 hours. I ended up just adding more spices to my flour bag at the end to try to give it SOME flavor.
This was really good. I only battered once. I used Garlic and Onion Salt instead to kick up the flavor and it worked!

What a terrible recipe. I’ve been cooking for 54 years. My husband & sons & other family members always enjoyed my food.

One of the things I’ve never been able to accomplish was good fried chicken. My mom’s mom (granny) always made the best pan fried chicken. Crispy, golden brown & juicy. 

When I was a teen & into my 20’s, I would watch granny make her fried chicken. Mixed together flour, salt, black pepper, paprika. Rolled the wet chicken pieces in the flour mixture & fried chicken in a cast iron skillet. She made a beautiful cream gravy for the mashed potatoes.

My mom tried frying chicken & never was successful, same with me. I would end up with at best mediocre fried chicken along with a waste of my time, a greasy & flour mess in my kitchen!

After not making fried chicken for about 20 years, I thought my husband & I would make this recipe. Followed the recipe, except for Dijon mustard (I can’t imagine including this in fried chicken). Soaked the chicken, breaded it & let set on a rack for 30 minutes. Used a cast iron skillet, used our temperature gauge to try & keep the oil @ 350 degrees. It took quite awhile to fry the chicken, leaving an oily & flour mess.

The chicken got too dark, breading was soft not crunchy (I was wondering about the wisdom of including baking powder in the flour), the breading was flat tasting.

NEVER again will I make fried chicken! KFC for us.

I wanted this to be good so badly. It was not. I wanted to try a new way to fry chicken. Every single bit of this crust fell off my chicken and I ended up with nekkid as a jaychicken pieces. Served the blobs of crust on the side and advised hubby to interchange bites. It had pretty good flavor but nothing to write home about. I'm stickin with my tried and true Grandmother's approach, which involved nothing more than salt, pepper, flour and fry it up. THAT worked. I'm sorry, but this is a 1 star for me. And indeed, I did not change a thing.
Delicious!
Is was excellent. Hubby loves fried chicken and for him to like it so much I know it had to be good. The only think I did not do was dip it twice.

Seasoning and marinade were spot on. Chicken was very tender and juicy. The only part that I wasn’t crazy about was the skin. I’ve been in the South all my life and Southern Fried chicken is crispy. This wasn’t.!!

I marinated for 2 hours and followed the recipe exactly. I was expecting to taste some of the cayenne or even the garlic and onion. Next time I will double the amount of seasoning and marinate overnight to see if I get more flavor out of it.

Good recipe! Reminds me of my Grandmother's fried chicken. I added 3 tablespoons of butter to the mix. I also let it cook (fry) for 16 minutes at 350 degrees in my electric fly pan, turning it after 8 minutes. I don't remember adding any other ingredients (except for butter) other than what was in the recipe.

Giving this recipe 5 stars principally because of how moist the chicken turns out after frying. The way the marinade and dry mixture finishes is the best I've seen and I used skinless tenders. 

The recipe can be improved by improvising with spices in the dry mixture. That'll really kick it up a notch with flavor!
The only thing I did different was I used only chicken thighs and legs. Smells wonderful and well liked in our home.
This is the best fried chicken recipe and I've tried a few. The only thing I did was added a tbs. of Creole seasoning.

I made this the other night using boneless, skinless chicken breasts that I'd cut into strips for chicken fingers and it was fantastic! I followed the marinade instructions exactly and marinaded the chicken in the fridge for about 6 hours. Based on other reviews I added some extra seasoning to the flour (1 tsp white pepper, 1 tsp chipotle chili powder, and a quick sprinkle of cayenne). To my surprise, the dipping and dredging process went very quickly. In fact I'm considering doing it 3 times next time to get it super crispy! I let the tenders "rest" for about 30 mins while I heated the oil and then fried them up. It was fantastic and I will definitely make this again.
I put in Mrs Dash original blend instead of mustard, and I added 1/2 tsp of smoked paprika. SO good!!
I will definitely make this again, it was delicious!

I used 1/2-n-1/2 instead of buttermilk and added maybe 1/8 tsp. of cayenne since we were making this for kids. It is absolutely fantastic! Only recipe we will use now. Pro-tip - Boil the drumsticks before cooking them and then if needed finish them out by baking them in the oven.

As a southern girl I have had my share of great fried chicken and this recipe is right up there. After reading some of the other reviews about the breading being bland I added a teaspoon of season salt and a teaspoon of Emerill’s Essence to the flour mixture. The flavor was perfect. 

 I did double dip the chicken as the recipe indicated and the breading was great, not too heavy. I used boneless skinless chicken breasts and cooked them in a cast iron skillet...a must for great fried chicken.
Used fresh Chicken Tenders with Lemon Pepper and Curry instead of Black Pepper and Cayenne... was absolutely delicious. I will definitely be making this often.
I made no changes to the recipe and it turned out great! You gotta try it.
Very good so far the best fried chicken I have ever had.
i used almond flour-not good because it was too absorbent and i used coconut oil and the meat soaked it up and coating came off.
Love the crunchiness of the batter. I would like to add a bit more seasoning to it though. Overall very impressed.
The boys loved it.

I marinated 4 hours before I fried it in peanut oil The crispy coating was delicious and the tang of the buttermilk combined with Louisiana Hot Sauve gave it a little bite. Loved this recipe with roasted potatoes and corn on the cob (in season)
Didn't have a whole chicken but I took boneless/skinless breast cut them into disc and they were so good, I don't like breast had them for family who likes it but I enjoyed them this way.

I made this last night. it was big disaster. I followed the recipe but it was too dark. not done and bland. I will stick to my own favorite. yes I set the fryer at 335 for the first batch. burnt and raw. then turned it down to 270. raw a greasy. ugh. I had such high hopes for it.
Used minced onion. Soaked chicken in buttermilk for 8 hours. Added seasonings to buttermilk. We used a quart of buttermilk. We fried chicken in a deep fat frier.

No Changes are necessary. So far, I'm just experimenting with trying out different recipes. I will keep it for a family favorite. It was good hot & fresh, but it wowed my family cold, probably a great mainstay for picnics! :) :)
These were super crunchy! I made little chicken bites and they cooked perfectly. I might add a little bit more spices next time to give it some heat.
Great Mix, thanks will be a repeat at my house.
It was okay. I wasn't crazy about the batter. I think the double dip made too much better and it was lacking something. Not much flavor.
Exceptional! Very easy and boy are they tasty! My grandkids loved them and so did I. Great granddaughter helped and wants to show her mom how to make them. Kudos to me!
This chicken was really good. Like other reviews, the only thing I would change is doubling up on the ingredients. Had flavor but not as much as I would have liked. Will definitely make it again.
Que delicious !!! Followed the recipe and it turned out delicious. Even fried some pickles and zucchini with the same batter too. Mmmmm good!

I didn't use buttermilk but milk with a teaspon of vinegar since I didn't have buttermilk. I will need to retry with the proper buttermilk. Otherwise, I felt it was really bland and I would have appreciated the flavors of the mustard and everything else. The crust was really bland and so I will try to see if I can make another batch that is more flavorable.
Super easy recipe to make. I let my chicken sit over night in the buttermilk and I fried the chicken on medium heat. It help to not burn the chicken and the oil. Big hit with the family!!!
loved it first time making this

This recipe did not work for me at all even though I followed it exactly and marinated it 8 hours. It was very bland and the coating did not stick to the chicken. I will stick to my easy fried chicken recipe of dipping chicken in egg then a mixture of flour, corn starch, garlic salt and seasoning salt, let the coated chicken sit until it gets tacky before frying. (corn starch does this and keeps the coating on the chicken). Easy and tasty!

Wonderful! Great directions for success. I love to cook but was intimidated by fried chicken for some reason. This recipe explained what I needed to know, and it was delicious the first time. 

I gave 5 stars because the recipe is great as is. Next time I feel confident to get creative with seasoning.
My husband and I Loved this chicken! But I think next time I'll put in a little more heat. We like things spicy.
I made it and it was great! The only change I made was leaving out the corn starch as I didn't want it extra crispy. Cooked it outside on a side burner of my grill in a 12" cast iron fry pan!
This was too bland for me. I didn't taste any southern flavors but it DID come out super nice and crispy. We had to add more flavor after frying.
It was very good, it had a lil too much coating on it so maybe just one flip in flour and a lil more salt n pepper, def will try again.
We used this recipe tonight to make boneless chicken wings. The breading was spot on. I've added this to my list of favorites.

This recipe is excellent. Followed it exactly except fried the chicken in a deep fryer at 325 so the meat would be done without getting the crust too brown. Also added cayenne to marinade and flour for a little extra bite. This is my new fried chicken recipe.

Great stuff. All I changed was to add cayenne pepper and paprika to the flour. I did Double coat and bake to finish.
Awesome

This was my first time making fried chicken, and it was absolutely amazing! I took some tips from other reviews and added a fourth teaspoon of paprika to the dry ingredients, added a little extra salt and only dipped the chicken into the batter once. I cooked the chicken for about five minutes on each side, and it got so crispy! I made it with some corn and mashed potatoes and it was absolutely amazing!
Very good recipe. Didn't change a thing.

This is a keeper! Just made a few tweaks due to others saying it was bland. I put a few T of hot sauce in with the marinade and A LOT MORE spices than what it calls for. It wasn't spicy, just gull of flavor. I'm ditching my other fried chicken recipes for this one! Oh, one more thing, I made sure to allow the chicken to come to room temperature/slightly cool before breading it and I let the breading set up for about 30 minutes to ensure that the breading stayed on the chicken and not on my fryer ?
Will definitely make it again.
I think it's pretty good, I made it just as is. I think next time around I'll add a bit more of all the spicy stuff. I'll let you know...

Four stars as the printed recipe is a bit on the bland side. I added my own 11 Herbs & Spices to shame the Colonel! 325 oil temp, nothing hotter or you end up with uncooked chicken & burned coating. I also finely chopped fresh thyme & added it to the buttermilk along with Smoked Paprika and triple the cayenne pepper. Far better results.
I used French's mustard rather than Dijon and it was really good! This recipe was simple and delicious! I plan to make it many times more!

The southern girl in me was craving some down home country cookin' so i looked thru some recipes and decided on this! WOW! The best I've ever made! I followed the directions to the T and it came out perfectly! I did find that i needed more flour than the 2 cups stated in the recipe and about half way thru the battering of the chicken in flour, i decided to use a big plate instead of a plastic bag, and it worked better for me. I made mashed potatoes with country gravy and fresh chopped spinach with melted butterand salt. I loved it and so did my family! I have made other recipes and they really didn't work out that great but this one is a keeper for sure! Thank you for sharing!

Liked it, but I wish it were a little spicier. Maybe I'll add some cayenne to the flour mix, too. We put it on Cornish hens and put them in the deep fryer, so maybe took some of the flavor away. Will for sure make again.

Heard a few stories about buttermilk fried chicken and how good it is so I found a few recipes & this 1 caught my eye. I made this as the directions stated & I'm very impressed. Great all around. I will definitely put this in my recipe book & make again. Only thing I will try next time is omit the seasons & replace with Old Bay, I love Old Bay in my fried chicken with a coating of honey every now & then. The original recipe is a keeper thank you very much.

I agree with others, you need to double or possibly triple the spices. It could be very good, but we found if made as is, it is very bland. Nice crunch to the coating though, and the chicken was moist.

I am reviewing the buttermilk marinade only. It made for the most moist and delicious chicken. I took some other reviewers suggestions and let my drumsticks marinate overnight (by the time I cooked the chicken it was probably about 14 hours). I skinned them first because I hate the skin that much, threw together some breadcrumbs and seasonings for my coating, and baked the drumsticks at 375 for about 45 minutes, turning once. My party guests loved it and I got a ton of compliments! The chicken was so moist and tender with just a kick of heat. I will use this marinade over and over again.

I only had skinless, boneless chicken breasts on hand. So I cut them up & then used this recipe to make tenders. Followed it except for 1 item, added hot sauce to the batter. Probably will add more the next time, need an extra kick.

I was very disappointed as the crust did not stick to the chicken. I did add more seasonings and the taste was good. But my family would not eat this.. I will try again and pat the chicken dry after the marinade. Just disappointed as it was a time consuming recipe
Followed the recipe and it was WONDERFUL.
Tried it tonight and it was extremely juicy but bland. Will make it again but will add lots more spices - more like Colonel Saunders.

Did one coating, as most reviewers suggested and it was more than enough. I have no idea how two flour coatings would look like. 
Kept in buttermilk over night. It could have had more flavor, though I did add salt and paprika into flour, and skipped onion powder. Made wing drumsticks and boneless thighs, so it didn't burn until it was done, but I do believe bigger pieces would have burnt on the outside (I've read oil temperature on thermometer, so it wasn't too hot). 
Will only use this recipe as the guideline for variations with spices and flavors.

I'm an above-average home cook, but this was my first attempt at fried chicken. I would have appreciated some general guidelines on how long to fry the different pieces - I used chicken thighs and it was trial and error with the oil and the timing so that the chicken was cooked and moist without the coating being nearly burnt. Thank goodness I bought a value pack, because my first batch didn't leave very many edible pieces! I have a better sense now, but more detail in the recipe would have been helpful.

We loved this recipe and my husband is not a big chicken fan. I heeded the advice from other cooks and omitted the onion and garlic powder. Instead I added salt and paprika. I also added 1/2 cup of cornmeal to the flour. Not only did that add flavor but it also added crunch and a great texture. I like lots of crunch so I followed suggestions to double dip. The recipe did not have a suggested oil temp. So I used my deep fryer and set it to 350. The chicken browned beautifully but too quickly to cook the legs I was using so I fried first then placed the legs on a rack over a cookie sheet. The legs finished cooking in the oven at 350 for 30 minutes. The outside was golden, crunchy and the meat tender and very moist. I will definitely make this again.

This recipe was good. My first time ever making fried chicken the traditional way. I changed a few things - added hot sauce to the marinade, and instead of using dijon I used boar's head gourmaise which is highly seasoned since I read reviews saying it was slightly bland. I also recommend letting the chicken sit for 30 mins or so after coating and before frying so you don't lose the breading in the oil like I did!

We have made this recipe so many times. It is always amazing. Best fried chicken I have ever had. We use boneless chicken breasts for it and it works fantastically. Every time we make this for people, they rave about it. Highly recommend this recipe.
I did not care for this.

Did not add the mustard, and added a splash of Frank's Louisiana Hot sauce to the buttermilk and left out the cayenne. I did however add a little cayenne to the flour dredge along with the other spices. This was and is the BEST fried chicken I have ever made. It was fantastic. It was juicy and flavorful and crunchy. None of the crust came off in the pan as some have experienced. My husband said it was most definitely the best fried chicken I have ever made. For the few times a year I will make this. no guilt whatsoever on the fried/calorie laden dish. You won't be sorry if you make this one! Thanks for the recipe!

This was great! The only thing I did differently was use thin cut chicken breast and put the seasonings in the bag with the buttermilk and chicken instead of in the flour. I was able to let it marinate for 3hrs and it was awesome!! I made mashed potatoes with it and used McCormick brand country gravy over the chicken and mashed potatoes. Best, most tender chicken I've ever had!

This is by far the worst chicken recipe I've ever tried. The breading burnt (do an egg wash instead of the marinade...I did that with two pieces, cooked in the oven rather than fried and they looked like kfc!). Seasonings were lack luster; again except the two I put in the oven where I added garlic, tarragon, more onion, paprika, and cayenne.

I baked the chicken thighs in the oven the night before, so it made for less frying time. In the morning I made the buttermilk mixture and let the chicken marinate for 8-9 hrs. I did make a change by adding paprika as per another review suggestion. I believe I will cut back on the flour by 1/2 cup next time. I used boneless/skinless thighs. My husband liked it and he is from KY.
This recipe gets my family's approval. The chicken is flavorful and the crust is perfectly crispy. I'll definitely be making this one again.

I tried this recipe on the weekend and my family LOVED it. I was concerned that the amount of Cayenne pepper might be excessive, but it was just right. 
I don't remember the last time I made Southern Fried Chicken, but, my family loved it enough to request a repeat!

I tried this recipe and it came out great! I did follow some of the other reviews and not double dip. The first time I made it I did and it didn't taste as flavorful to me but the second time wow! Great flavor and so good. I also marinated the chicken in the buttermilk over night. My family loved it!
I won't be making this again.

I used this recipe as my starting point, I subbed Louisiana hot sauce for the Dijon mustard in the marinade, and I doubled the salt. Also omitted the cayenne pepper. For the dredge, I decreased garlic powder to 1 1/2 tsp, omitted onion powder and added 1 tbsp paprika ( something my mom did) fried in butter cris o, and it was AMAZING!!
This was a great recipe, nice and crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Could use some more flavor, but that could be my fault since I only marinated for 2 hours.

Thank you many times for this incredible recipe! I'm a single adult male. I almost always ate outside until this year. I always disliked spending time in the kitchen previously. Now that I work from home and also for the cost cutting reasons, I decided to learn cooking a little bit recently. I'd like to mention that I always stayed away from fried food except french fries I occasionally (once a year or or so) ate at Mc Donald's and etc. I came across this website and the recipe while searching to know how to cook Country Style Chicken which I accidentally watched on a TV show. Theirs was different but i read your recipe and it seemed simple. Normally, I won't bother trying out anything that has more than 4 ingredients and at least one of them is unknown to me which I may never use again. Anyhow, the only different thing I did was I used reduced fat buttermilk with two thick and large pieces of chicken breasts cut into 10 pieces (drumstick size) which I bought to cook Curry Chicken with Coconut Milk. I said"what the heck!"I just served it with white rice and flax seeds. I couldn't wait to give your recipe 5 stars and tell my experience. I took two bites and my reaction "OH, MY GOD!"Seriously! It was crispy&yummy. The chicken breast melted in my mouth! Btw, after a few bites, I decided to add some hot ketchup sauce (like buffalo sauce) on the side. Thnx 2 Utube,I used the left over marinade IMMEDIATELY to bake some biscuits-made my 1st ever dough and biscuits. :-)

The chicken didn't have a flavor at all. I used everything from the recipe. The coating was very flaky and it was a beautiful golden brown. I will not make this again unless there is something I could add to bring in more flavor. I'm not sure why it received 5 stars, because it is bland like chicken from a hospital cafeteria.

The chicken didn't have a flavor at all. I used everything from the recipe. The coating was very flaky and it was a beautiful golden brown. I will not make this again unless there is something I could add to bring in more flavor. I'm not sure why it received 5 stars, because it is bland like chicken from a hospital cafeteria.

I did not care for this recipe. The flour mixture was absolutly NOT enough to cover all of the chicken pieces ONCE, Let alone TWICE!!!! So please, at least triple the flour part if you want enough to cover everything twice. Secondly, after I stopped 1/3 of the way through, to triple my flour, when I finally got it all covered and redipped twice, I fried it as directed. ONLY TO WATCH EVERY LAST BIT OF FLOUR BREADING come right off in the hot oil.

This was a good start. I double dipped and the texture of the breading was perfect. The buttermilk marinade was great. My one complaint is that the flour coating was bland, even when i added more salt / pepper and the addition of paprika to the flour mixture. This needs A LOT more salt and pepper. Will definitely make again with changes.

I have tried a few fried chicken recipes on this site and this one is a keeper we loved it thank you for sharing and I kept my chicken in buttermilk all night and doubled the spices and turned out yummy
What an easy task. Other then moving chicken between bags. The setup was easy and frying was easy. The eating was the best part!!
I give 3 stars only because it needs more seasoning. But very crispy outside and juicy on inside. Will use more spices next try
Finally got,it right with this recipe never put baking powder in the flour before and that is the secret to making it stay on and become crispy. Loved it hubby was well pleased. Yeah!
We just Love this recipe!!! So full of flavor! Y'all need to try this one! :)
buttermilk didnt give any different taste coating just fell off legs while cooking.
Delish. Entire family loved it.

I only make fried chicken once a year. This year I tried this recipe after trying others by celebrity chefs and "lifestyle mavens" other years in search for the perfect recipe.This one is by far the best. One thing I swear by is having an electric skillet. It keeps an even temp for the oil and you don't have to guess when oil is at right temperature. My chickens were perfectly crunchy and omnom-y.. Until next year!

Must increase the spices/salt otherwise the chicken will be bland. I have also found that one dip is enough. Other wise its too thick and the batter burns a little. Do not crowd the chicken as well. So you will be cooking for a while. This also renders the oil useless for those of that like to re-use oil.
This recipe is great, add in my own extra seasoning for a little more kick.

So good and so simple! My husband and I made this just yesterday and it was delicious! The only change I would (will) make is more pepper, but I like to follow directions exactly the first time around before making adjustments. ;) I will definitely keep this recipe around!
This is the way chicken supost to b
The coating wouldn't stick

Takes a while but worth it. Ended up using only legs as that's what I had. Put a ton of extra seasoning in the flour mix but it didn't hold in, though the chicken itself was amazing. Hubby ate half of it by himself.

I myself am giving it a 4 but my grown daughter gives it a 5. I did keep to the recipe except I did add some salt and pepper to the flour mixture. I kept chicken in buttermilk mixture 3 hrs, I'll do longer next time. I thought it was good but next time I might add more more seasoning for myself. Make sure your oil isn't too hot and you won't burn it. I started out on med and then moved it a little lower after I flipped the chicken. 15 mins on each side for me but you really need to watch it while cooking. Don't let your oil overheat. The breading was a little tougher than I'm use to.
